results.title: Sale Reveur = Dirty Dreamer
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Perier, Daniele Delorme and Yves Robert
results.brief_description:
Jerome, is a stuntcar racer still living out teenage fantasies of being Paul Newman. Although surrounded by an urban jungle of parking lots and high rise towers, he likes to think of himself as ‘Hud’ and his long suffering girlfriend does nothing to play down the fantasy.

Credits: Producers, Yves Robert, Daniele Delorme ; director, Jean-Marie Perier ; writers, Jean-Marie Perier, Pascal Jardin, Lucien Elia ; photography, Yves Lafaye ; music, Sydney Bechet, Jacques Dutronc ; decors, Theo Meurisse.
Cast: Jacques dutronc, Lea Massari, Jean Bouise, Maurice Benichou, Nathalie Perier, Greg Germain, Anemone.

results.title: Salamanders
results.creator_credit: Madeline McLaughlin and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Suzuki outlines the amazing diversity of salamanders, their ability to regenerate limbs, to clone themselves and to adapt physically (both internally and externally) to their environment.
results.description: David Suzuki outlines the amazing diversity of salamanders, their ability to regenerate limbs, to clone themselves and to adapt physically (both internally and externally) to their environment.

results.title: Salaam Bombay!
results.creator_credit: Mira Nair, Channel 4, Cadrage (Paris) and Mirabai Films
results.brief_description: Abandoned by the travelling fair for which he works, 11 year old Krishna takes a train to the nearest city - Bombay. He is initiated into the ways of the city by various members of a children’s street gang and, determined to save up enough money to get home, begins work at the bottom of the street hierarchy as a “Chaipau” or tea-boy. Through his eyes we glimpse a Bombay never seen in traditional Indian studio-based films, a city of madness and cacophony, where flesh and drugs are traded and everywhere there are children like Krishna, surviving and succumbing to the appetite of the raging metropolis. Movingly acted by real street kids this film is an eloquent addition to the cinema’s portraits of troubled childhood.

results.title: Sailor Moon. Ep 8: The Doom tree strikes [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Junichi Sato, Louise Hurtubise and Toei Animation
results.brief_description: Six episodes of the Japanese animated television series, “Sailor Moon”, entitled “The doom tree strikes”. The setting is Cross Roads Junior High School, and Serena, a young girl possesses a magical brooch that invokes mystical forces, transforming her into the powerful Sailor Moon, a super-heroine whose mission is to protect humanity from evil demons from a parallel universe. Fellow Sailor Scouts, Jupiter, Mercury and Mars join her on her adventures. Episodes featured are: “A Knight to remember” When a monstrous creature attacks the Sailor crew, a mysterious knight (could it be Darien?) comes to the rescue; “VR madness” A virtual reality theatre is the location for the mega-verse’s latest assault, but without her tiara, Serena is helpless to aid her imperilled family. “Cherry blossom time” Sailor Moon and her friends are in danger when they are captured by alien beings. “Kindergarten chaos” Several potent beings with malevolent intentions threaten the lives of kindergarten children, until the Sailor crew intervene. “Much ado about babysitting” Darien and Sailor Moon baby-sit together whilst evil forces try to rob babies of their energy. “Raye’s day in the spotlight” Raye organises and stars in the Autumn festival but a monster from a mega-verse makes a guest appearance. Based on the original comic “Sailor Moon” by Naoko Takeuchi, the series is underpinned by the decent moral codes of friendship, honesty, responsible behaviour, respect and selflessness.

results.title: Sailor beware = Panic in the parlour
results.creator_credit: Gordon Parry, Jack Clayton, Romulus Films and British Lion Films
results.brief_description: From the stage play “Sailor beware” by Philip King and Falkland L. Cary with an introduction by Bill Collins. A humorous tale of domestic conflict between Shirley (Shirley Eaton), her prospective sailor husband-to-be Albert (Ronald Lewis) and Shirley’s overbearing acerbic tongued mother, Emma (Peggy Mount). Cast includes Cyril Smith, Esme Cannon, Gordon jackson, Geoffrey Keen, Joy Webster, Thora Hird.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gordon Parry, Jack Clayton, Romulus Films and British Lion Films

results.title: Sail away
results.creator_credit: Bruce Mackay, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A boy named Gus accepts an invitation to spend several days aboard the trimaran Freya. During the cruise he is instructed in the rudiments of sailing and is entrusted with the helm. Ever curious, Gus is taught to identify various forms of marine life. There is a particularly striking sequence of a storm at sea that Gus, the skipper, and the Freya ride out handsomely.

results.title: Sagittarius/Domain + Prelude
results.credit_line:
Shaun Gladwell
Dual-channel video installation
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, 2 channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
“Sagittarius/Domain + Prelude” is a dual-channel video installation commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences” in 2011.

“Sagittarius/Domain + Prelude” sits in an enclosed room, two screens facing each other on opposite walls. In both, a lone figure tracked from behind – the camera employing a classical point of view, mimicking the work of Caspar David Friedrich – descends into a subterranean passageway. For the viewer these figures act like avatars, our perspective being theirs, one moment behind.

On the first screen, Sagittarius, a figure moves tentatively through a warren of dark, damp caves and tunnels in the Wollemi National Park carrying a bow and flaming arrow that lights the way. The figure’s movements are captured on infra-red camera – a night vision system Gladwell also used in “Double Field’” (2010) – the otherworldly landscape of the cave system caught in greenish tones. The footage is grainy and raw, only hinting at the richness of the ecosystem hidden deep inside the earth.

On the second screen, filmed in the underground in the Domain in inner Sydney, is a skateboarder propelling himself down a travelator (once famously the longest travelator in the world). The natural world in such abundance in the Wollemi caves is overwhelmed by the concrete and metal of this man-made tunnel. Yet there is a similarity in tone, the fluorescent glow of the travelator scene shedding a similar light to that in the cave sequence. The skateboarder uses his hands to propel himself down the travelator until the power of gravity takes over, assuming a fixed position, hands and legs held out to the side, to stabilise his descent.

results.title: Safety in your hands
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Jill Robb, John Fitzgerald and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1974 film examines the responsibility of each worker for their own safety in the workplace. The film focuses particularly on protection of hands and eyes in industrial settings, showing a variety of machines operated by people. It demonstrates how untidiness, inattention, overconfidence and failure to use safety precautions such as safety glasses when operating these machines can lead to accidents. Footage of industrial workplaces is interspersed with footage of everyday accidents similarly caused by mess, distraction and overconfidence.

Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
